description: From Middle English commoditee, from Anglo-Norman commoditee, from Latin commoditās.

entries.meaning: Anything movable (a good) that is bought and sold. [from 15th c.]
examples: If a key part of shopping is the conversion of anonymous commodities into possessions, shopping is a cultural as much as an economic activity.

And Slade said: "It really makes me sad that football club chairmen and boards seem to have lost that most precious commodity - patience. "Sam's sacking at Newcastle had, I suppose, been on the cards for a while, but it is really ridiculous to fire a manager after such a short time.

entries.meaning: (economics) Raw materials, agricultural and other primary products as objects of large-scale trading in specialized exchanges.
examples: The price of crude oil is determined in continuous trading between professional players in World's many commodities exchanges.

entries.meaning: (marketing) Undifferentiated goods characterized by a low profit margin, as distinguished from branded products.
examples: Although they were once in the forefront of consumer electronics, the calculators have become a mere commodity.

entries.meaning: (Marxism) Anything which has both a use-value and an exchange-value.
(obsolete) Self-interest; personal convenience or advantage. [16th–19th c.]
